channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: N.Z. says yes to same-sex marriage
item.description: The competitive spirit between Australia and New Zealand rarely dims, but New Zealand has sprinted ahead of its trans-Tasman rival to become the first country in the Asia Pacific region to legalize same-sex marriage.

item.title: 3 new planets could host life
item.description: Scientists discover three planets that are some of the best candidates so far for habitable worlds outside our own solar system.

item.title: Boeing's new 747-8: Same but different
item.description: Few feats of engineering are synonymous with an entire industry.

item.title: Wreck survivor recalls high seas drama
item.description: On the prairies of Illinois, Quen Cultra labored in his barnyard on another absurdity: building a boat to sail around the world.

item.title: Vodafone to 'bank' 700 million Indians
item.description: For the majority of people in the West banking is as easy as walking to a local branch or ATM, or logging into their account from a computer. But for millions in developing countries, even having a bank account is out of reach. In India, at least, that could be about to change.

item.title: Why amputees never say 'I can't'
item.description: Waking up to realize you suddenly have no leg or legs is as horrible an experience as one can have, and one that will, sadly, be faced by a number of people injured in the bombing of the Boston Marathon. It happened to me when I was 16 after a bone cancer diagnosis and amputation (the cancer later spread to my lung and caused a lung to be removed as well). As I looked down in the recovery room to where my right leg used to be, all I saw was a short stump.

item.title: How U.S. can gain from the new Mexico
item.description: Jason Marczak says immigration reform needs to be tailored to take advantage of the new, improved Mexico of today, not yesterday.

item.title: Why Justin Bieber should zip it
item.description: Just when you think teen superstar Justin Bieber couldn't possibly do anything dumber, he does something that makes you do a double face palm. Bieber is truly achieving the impossible: He's making Lindsay Lohan look good.

item.title: Why robots are ready for takeoff
item.description: At Romotive, we are obsessed with robots. We're a team of nerds, and we grew up watching science fiction that prominently featured robots doing extraordinary things to help or protect their human counterparts. We figured that as adults, our lives would be better because of robots.

item.title: One bomb suspect killed in shootout; second on run
item.description: Police swarm through Boston trying to track down "suspect number 2," warning he is believed to be armed. They identify an officer killed during the manhunt.

item.title: Sources describe two brothers
item.description: The suspects involved in the Boston Marathon bombing were brothers from the Russian Caucasus who moved to Kazakhstan before coming to the United States several years ago, a source briefed on the investigation told CNN.

item.title: Police officer shot
item.description: A university police officer has died after being shot on the Massachusetts Institute of Technology campus in Cambridge.

item.title: Armed police sweep Boston homes
item.description: Boston police, armed with assault rifles, move building to building searching for a missing terror suspect.

item.title: Cameroon: French family freed
item.description: A French family kidnapped in northern Cameroon earlier this year has been released, the Cameroonian government said Friday.

item.title: Pakistan police arrest Musharraf
item.description: Pakistani police on Friday arrested former President Pervez Musharraf and presented him in court a day after a judge had canceled his bail in one of several cases he faces relating to his time in power.

item.title: What led to Musharraf's arrest
item.description: CNN explains events throughout the day that led to the house arrest of former Pakistani President Musharraf.

item.title: Venezuela to audit election results
item.description: Venezuela's top election official said Thursday that authorities will complete a 100% audit of votes cast in Sunday's presidential election.

item.title: WHO to China: Chicken safe to eat
item.description: More cases of bird flu have been reported in China taking the total number of infections to 87, according to state news agency Xinhua.

item.title: Texas authorities scour blast area
item.description: A day after a fiery explosion ripped through the heart of a close-knit central Texas town, many questions remain.

item.title: Watch as huge blast rocks plant
item.description: Watch video of the moment a burning West, Texas, fertilizer plant erupts in a massive explosion.

item.title: Testimony nullified in genocide trial
item.description: More than three weeks of testimony in the genocide trial of former Guatemalan dictator Efrain Rios Montt were nullified by a judge Thursday on procedural grounds, state-run media reported.

item.title: Blast in Baghdad cafe kills at least 27
item.description: A bomb exploded Thursday night inside a popular coffee shop in western Baghdad, killing at least 15 people and wounding 21 others, city police officials told CNN.

item.title: Elvis impersonator on ricin charge
item.description: Test results were expected Thursday on letters possibly contaminated with the deadly poison ricin that were sent to President Barack Obama and Sen. Roger Wicker this week.

item.title: U.S. evacuations over flood threats
item.description: Record-setting rains in parts of the Midwest have caused hundreds of flight cancellations and flooding, with one northern Illinois hospital evacuating patients due to rising floodwaters.

item.title: Guinea-Bissau man accused of plot
item.description: U.S. prosecutors have accused the head of Guinea-Bissau's military of plotting to team up with Colombian rebels as part of a "narco-terrorist" operation.

item.title: UK and IMF face dust-up on austerity
item.description: George Osborne is to go toe-to-toe with the International Monetary Fund next month in a battle over the credibility of his Plan A on austerity for the UK, amid signs that incoming Bank of England governor Mark Carney will be a key ally in his fight.

item.title: Ireland picks through debtors' lifestyles
item.description: Irish homeowners applying for debt writedowns will have to give up satellite television, foreign holidays and private school educations for their children under a strict new insolvency law introduced to tackle the country's debt crisis.

item.title: Property prices soaring in Shanghai
item.description: Several major Chinese cities have implemented new controls on buying houses, as CNN's Patricia Wu reports.

item.title: Greece: Workers shot in wage dispute
item.description: Nearly 30 migrant workers in Nea Manolada, Greece, were wounded Wednesday after an apparent argument with their foremen over wages, police said Thursday.

item.title: Italy's Parliament votes for president
item.description: Italy's Parliament began casting votes Thursday for a new president to take the place of the incumbent Giorgio Napolitano, whose term expires next month.

item.title: Golf: Guan Tianlang invited to PGA event
item.description: Chinese golf prodigy Guan Tianlang will have another chance to shine at a top professional tournament after being invited to play in a PGA Tour event in New Orleans next week.

item.title: FBI: Help us ID suspects
item.description: After three days of poring over photos and video, investigators appealed to the public to help them identify two men now considered suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.

item.title: What we know
item.description: Two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings that killed three people may have terrorized the area a second time overnight. The latest developments:

item.title: 2 suspects 'acted differently'
item.description: After days of poring over photos and video, investigators release images of two suspects seen walking away "pretty casually" in the aftermath of the Boston Marathon bombings.

item.title: See video of the suspects
item.description: The FBI released photos and video of two suspects in the Boston Marathon terror attack.

item.title: 'You just watch things more closely'
item.description: The thought came to Don Walker during that most quintessential of American outings -- a baseball game.

item.title: Witness photos
item.description: CNN iReporters share their photographs and video taken shortly after two bombs exploded at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: How Korean war might play out
item.description: CNN's Tom Foreman and retired General James Marks map out potential strategies if North Korea attacks South Korea.

item.title: Wearable tech tracks your life
item.description: CNN takes a look at the future of interactive technology.

item.title: The evolution of the cell phone
item.description: CNN's Jim Boulden looks back to the first mobile phone call made 40 years ago.

item.title: Olympic swimmer goes for TV gold
item.description: Anderson Cooper has a preview of Ryan Lochte's upcoming E! reality TV show.

item.title: Are models getting thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Distraction: Cat walks dog
item.description: Everything is wrong about this. The natural order of things has been disrupted. Run for the hills!

item.title: Can 'Baby Federer' become a champion?
item.description: Nicknamed "Baby Federer" Bulgarian tennis ace, Grigor Dimitrov is hoping to move quickly up the rankings

item.title: Winning? There's more to life
item.description: Spanish golfer Miguel Angel -- who is lover of fine wine and cigars -- refuses to give up the good life in pursuit of sporting success.

item.title: Mysterious structure found under Galilee
item.description: A mysterious, circular structure, with a diameter greater than the length of a Boeing 747 jet, has been discovered submerged about 30 feet (9 meters) underneath the Sea of Galilee in Israel.

item.title: Man flies through 'Batcave' at 150 mph
item.description: Guy with wings flies at 150 mph through the "Batcave." Holy wingsuit! CNN's Jeanne Moos reports.

item.title: Harpooning Earth's orbital garbage
item.description: What do you do with 6,000 tons of space junk traveling at thousands of miles an hour? Harpoon it of course.

item.title: 3 new planets could host life
item.description: In the midst of chaos here on Earth, scientists are finding hope for life on other planets.

item.title: Visiting Myanmar: 11 things to know
item.description: Even if you're not planning a trip to Myanmar, take notes and fake it as a Burmese travel expert. Click here for advice on mohawks and more.

item.title: Bourdain on fetal duck egg
item.description: Piers Morgan challenges Anthony Bourdain to a taste test of some bizarre foods. Would you join in the challenge?

item.title: Rangers risk lives to save forest elephant
item.description: Last year, 60 park rangers were killed in the line of duty. But rangers in Cameroon are willing to risk their lives to save the African forest elephant.

item.title: Meet the team saving elephants
item.description: Inside Africa meets a team of conservationists and rangers working to save the animal from extinction.

item.title: U.S. drone strikes radicalize Pakistanis
item.description: The Sabaoon School for boys in northern Pakistan is anything but average.

item.title: Acid attack highlights Russian ballet battle
item.description: An acid attack on Bolshoi Theater's artistic director has put the spotlight on a battle for control of the world famous Russian institution.

item.title: Why North Korea 'has already won'
item.description: Even if the crisis ends right now, North Korea will have succeeded in sending a message across the world: that nuclear weapons make you untouchable, writes Frida Ghitis.

item.title: A beauty beyond skin deep
item.description: As a little girl, she never got a valentine at school parties.

item.title: 'Happy' Gilmore defies surfing cliches
item.description: Forget Point Break's party animals, modern surfing is more about professionalism.

item.title: How suicide shaped mom's gun views
item.description: I am a mother of three, and my views on guns have evolved significantly over the course of my lifetime. My husband hunts and believes strongly in his right to bear arms. But when my 25-year-old son, Peter, shot himself in a moment of despair in April 2012, I came full circle to a harsh reality: There are almost twice as many suicides as murders by firearm across America, roughly 19,000 of the 30,000 gun deaths each year. Yet we disproportionately fear and almost exclusively talk of criminals in the national gun debate.

item.title: Will we care about Web privacy in 2033?
item.description: The launch of the Facebook Home app has reignited the privacy debate over whether the social networking site is becoming too integrated in our lives.

item.title: Psy lightens mood with new single
item.description: As tensions on the Korean peninsula go up, Psy parties down and releases a new music video. CNN's Anna Coren reports.

item.title: Can social media clear pollution?
item.description: China is literally choking on itself. The rising tide of public outrage is an opportunity for China to get serious about pollution control, an expert says.

item.title: On China: Governing pollution
item.description: CNN's Kristie Lu Stout speaks with guests about governance problems behind severe pollution in China.

item.title: Neurotics shine in team settings
item.description: Give your anxious, negative colleagues a chance, and they just might surprise you.

item.title: Healing: Amputees never say 'I can't'
item.description: Those who lost legs in the Boston blasts face big challenges of body and especially mind but will succeed better than they imagine, writes amputee Jothy Rosenberg.

item.title: Bird flu and China's food traditions
item.description: China has one of the oldest food cultures in the world -- the food needs to be fresh. But problems arise with the way birds are handled.

item.title: North Korea's aging war machine
item.description: North Korea's conventional military assets are increasingly falling behind the capabilities of South Korea and the U.S.

item.title: China's role in climate change
item.description: CNN's Kristie Lu Stout speaks with guests about China's role in climate change and its impact on neighboring countries.

item.title: How CIA got back into killing
item.description: The story of how America's Central Intelligence Agency got back into the killing business after September 11th.

item.title: Trolls attack media critic
item.description: CNN's Ralitsa Vassileva talks to Anita Sarkeesian, creator of Feminist Frequency and a victim of online trolls.

item.title: Strangers save mother, teen
item.description: CNN's Gary Tuchman talks to a relative of some of the victims in the Boston Marathon bombing and shares their story.

item.title: Guantanamo prison: Why it's open
item.description: Obama has failed to meet his deadline to close Guantanamo prison because the world has stopped watching, a human rights organization says.

item.title: Inside Syrian town held by rebels
item.description: Nick Paton Walsh reports on a Syrian town held by militant and Jihadist rebels where the state control has collapsed.

item.title: Ending pandemics: How close are we?
item.description: A pandemic is one of the few things with the power to stop the global economy in its tracks. Dr. Larry Brilliant is confident that doesn't have to happen.

item.title: Teen beating odds after brain injury
item.description: I've proved the doctor wrong, and it motivates me to never let someone tell me what I can or cannot do.

item.title: Girl, 9, takes on Nadal
item.description: 9-year-old Rebecca Suarez stunned onlookers when she was pulled out of the crowd to team up with Del Potro against Nadal.

item.title: Beyonce: Poster child for success
item.description: Beyonce Knowles and those who have watched her rise to stardom talk about her life, career and dreaming big.

item.title: Tips for travelling with allergies
item.description: Don't let allergies derail your love of travel. Here's some tips from experts on dealing with various allergies when away from home.

item.title: London to Boston: 'We are with you'
item.description: Expect an ocean of black solidarity ribbons on the chests of runners in this weekend's London marathon.

item.title: Security increased for London
item.description: CNN's Dan Rivers reports on security challenges for the London Marathon after the attack at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: Why I fled North Korea
item.description: Hyeonseo Lee says when she was young she thought her country was normal, even though when she was 7 she saw her first public execution.

item.title: Rarely seen North Korea
item.description: The world is used to seeing glitzy military parades from North Korea but defectors paint a very different picture of the country -- one of people making soup out of grass and risking their lives to escape into China.

item.title: Witness: We heard explosions, gunshots
item.description: Boston residents describe hearing multiple explosions and gunshots in the Watertown area.

item.title: Boston manhunt
item.description: [Update 5:15 a.m.]

item.title: Plant explosion
item.description: A massive explosion at a fertilizer plant in the small Texas town of West left at least two people dead, leveled several homes and prompted a widescale evacuation in the community of 2,600 people.

item.title: Venezuela election
item.description: Venezuela's top election official said Thursday that authorities will complete a 100% audit of votes cast in Sunday's presidential election.

item.title: Syria warning
item.description: CNN's Nick Paton Walsh reports on a rare speech from Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Space debris
item.description: What do you do with 6,000 tons of space junk traveling at thousands of miles an hour? Harpoon it of course.

item.title: North Korea's demands
item.description: North Korea on Thursday set out demanding conditions for any talks with Washington and Seoul, calling for the withdrawal of U.N. sanctions against it and a permanent end to joint U.S.-South Korean military exercises.

item.title: Anthony Bordain
item.description: In some places of Koreatown you look around and swear you're in Asia. And yet, it's also 100% Los Angeles.

item.title: Budget woes delay climate reform
item.description: Not long after the European parliament cast doubt on the future of the EU's key policy to confront global warming, José Manuel Barroso, the European Commission president, huddled with his climate commissioner, Connie Hedegaard, in the VIP lounge at Strasbourg airport.

item.title: Dancing bears in India
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the inhumane tradition of bear dancing in India is fading out. Mallika Kapur reports.

item.title: Healthy living in Philippines
item.description: A major housing development in the Philippines tries to combine happy and healthy living. Pauline Chiou reports.

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: Bird flu and food traditions
item.description: China has one of the oldest food cultures in the world and, like that acme of Western food culture French cuisine, the food needs to be fresh.

item.title: China bird flu case count rises
item.description: Another case of bird flu has been reported in China, taking the total infection count to 83 people, as health authorities inside and outside the country try to determine how to stop its spread.

item.title: Local authority debt 'out of control'
item.description: A senior Chinese auditor has warned that local government debt is "out of control" and could spark a bigger financial crisis than the US housing market crash.

item.title: Guan invited to PGA Tour event
item.description: Chinese golf prodigy Guan Tianlang will have another chance to shine at a top professional tournament after being invited to play in a PGA Tour event in New Orleans next week.

item.title: China invites bird flu experts
item.description: Doctors say the discovery of a 4-year-old carrier of the H7N9 bird flu virus who shows no symptoms of the potentially lethal virus is a worrying development that could make the spread of the infection more difficult to monitor.

item.title: Zao Wou-ki: Painting beyond words
item.description: The Chinese-French painter Zao Wou-ki once told me that painting expresses the thoughts we struggle to put into words. Faced with this challenge, "It's easier to learn English!" he joked, his wit shining through, even though Alzheimer's disease had already begun its slow, relentless onslaught on his mind.

item.title: Can China convince Kim to cool it?
item.description: As North Korea's long-term ally, analysts say China has the greatest potential leverage over the country's young leader. But is it likely to assert itself and would Kim Jong Un even listen?
